 7. The best thing is that an analyst does everything but actual analysis.

MASSIVE AND POOR HIRING:The management is completely directionless here. They hired ~400 campus recruits for this year without proper estimation. This ultimately lead to huge inflow of people in teams beyond their requirements.  The result is that everybody is frustrated. In most of the teams, hardly 1-2 out of 10 actually work. Moreover their hiring standards have become questionable.

NO VISION: No new major feature or product is in pipeline. Although everybody is busy reporting bugs to show their presence, no-body is taking initiative to improve the UI experience as whole. I have not heard even a single word from CPO and CTO about their vision for SD and how they plan to take things forward.

BLAME-GAME AND POLITICS: Teams are busy in passing the buck rather than taking the ownership. The current system is still in messy shape. There are redundant systems all around but no body is coming forward to clean it. They rather prefer to stay idle.

NO PLANNING: PM just keeps on adding releases and features which ultimately never go live. Loyalty points is one that I can remember.

UNEVEN APPRAISAL:  Some teams have gotten huge appraisal even though their system remains in pathetic state. And some teams even though

headline: Fast paced culture with good career growth
pros:
I joined Snapdeal last year, honestly not expecting what I was getting into given I came from a top tier consulting firm. But I was pretty tired with making powerpoints and wanted a "real" job. So, here is my assessment over the last year:

Irrespective of how smart you are, you will find people who are really smart and committed to what they do. But good thing is that no one makes a big deal of that, so the environment is pretty genial.

For a 1000+ strong company, the company does a pretty good job of keeping everyone at all levels on the same page in terms of the company's near term goals. So, as an employee, you don't feel left out or lost or have existential questions about why you are doing what you are doing.

Finally, from my perspective, and this is something many of my colleagues who come from a similar top tier engineering + MBA background also feel, there is a feeling of challenge that I didn't feel when I would come to work at my prior consulting job. Before joining here I didn't think I would be in a situation reasonably often when I really had to rack my brain for answers.
cons: Given the company is very aggressive about the pace it wants to move at, there is still a scrappy start-up feel to the company, which means there may not be the same structured approach to HR and the perks that one has at the top tier consulting type firms may be missing such as lots of free team dinners and drinks, offsites, abroad travel at least once a year, etc. But then again, that is a choice you have to make. I am pretty content with giving up the mega perks in return for high intensity learning.

cons:
There have been so many reviews of Snapdeal's technical team, some really bad, some really good. I guess both do not give the true picture and both are biased in their own ways.

1. The work load of technical team here is quite unbalanced, where some people are slogging themselves and some are sitting pretty and frankly they can not be blamed because that is the expectations of the upper management. 

2. Mostly Knowing the right people is the key to succeed here, not doing the right thing.

3. In the technical team, if you want to get hired, here is a tip for you. "I dont code", "Coding is against my religion", "I am more of an architecture guy" are the kind of phrases actually get you hired here. 

4. That is the reason that some people are sitting pretty while junior employees are doing most of the work. and thus the dissatisfaction by them and high satisfaction by seniors.

5. I think Snapdeal's tech team lost touch with reality a long back, that for technically sound product good people need to write good code. But no, here mediocre code is written by freshers who do not know any better and all the seniors are assuming more "responsible" roles i.e. fighting with product teams, procrastinating on issues till death, doing the almost always inconclusive, no concrete action plan, I am the best sort of "brain-storming" sessions etc.

6. Due to these problems, a could've been a technical power horse, a team of 150 able youngsters has turned into a mediocre bureaucracy where it is too much to keep the site up and running to do any innovation unlike any great company like Amazon etc.

7. And yes, as for the girls here: The gender ratio is pretty decent. I think it is a good thing for guys and girls. Girls, you will not be singled out here. But yes, you will have to put up with some rude behavior and pan shop like abuses. These elements are fringe, but yes there will be no action against them. 

Final advice: It is a good company if you want to have a job for a year or two. come here, learn, get good money, do some good work and leave. Come here with the spirit of "Na sammaan ki chaah, na apmaan ka bhay!"
